This will be the tenth loan which Luz has had from MFP and she pledges to make her repayments in a timely manner because she does not want to give a bad impression to the people who, through funding her loan, will allow her to continue working in search of progress.  Luz plans to invest the loan in the purchase of 2 video games in order to begin her future business which she says she will improve her income.

loans.use: To purchase two video games in order to set up her business

loans.name: Veronica Segundina

texts.es:
Verónica es socia del Banco Comunal “Santiago Apóstol” ubicado en el distrito de Paucarcolla, provincia de Puno, departamento de Puno, tiene 40 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, tiene cuatro hijos y con grado de instrucción de educación primaria  incompleta.
Verónica viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace cinco años, el primer préstamo solicitado fue de S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual pudo usar en su negocio de venta de pescado específicamente Karachi y pejerrey.
Ahora solicitara un nuevo préstamo de S/ 1000.00 nuevos soles, préstamo que invertirá en su negocio.
Su sueño es seguir adelante con su negocio. Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal  es la solidaridad.
texts.en:
Verónica is a member of the Communal Bank “Santiago Apóstol”, which is located in the District of Paucarcolla, Province and Department of Puno. She is 40 years old, in a common law marriage, and has four children. Verónica did not finish her elementary school education.

She has been working with Manuela Ramos for five years. The first loan she requested was for 300 PEN, which she used for her business of selling fish, especially “carache” and “pejerrey”.

Now she is requesting a new loan in the amount of 1000 PEN to invest in her business. Verónica’s dream is to continue forward with her business. What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank is the solidarity.

loans.use: Operating capital for selling fish

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas is a thirty-eight-year-old married man who is blessed with five children. He lives in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He aspires to have an educated family and become a model household in the village. He sells firewood for a living. He has been in the field for three years and it has enabled him to pay school fees for his children. His passion is to have a store that supplies a bigger area. Thomas needs the loan to purchase firewood to sell.

loans.use: To buy firewood to sell

loans.name: Juliana Anamoa

texts.en: Juliana Anamoa M. sells soft drinks at Akotokyir, near Abura. She is married and has been in this business for five years now. She assists her husband in taking care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more soft drinks to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to reinvest the additional income as a result of the loan.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena A. sells smoked fish, fried fish and fante kenkey, a food staple made from fermented maize dough wrapped in leaves.  Abena has been educated through junior high school.  She is married and has four children. Her husband taps palm trees for palm wine to make a living, and Abena assists her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. 

She sells her goods in Takoradi and demand is high.  Abena is looking to expand her business to increase her profit. She wishes to increase production and sales, so she is asking for a loan to buy fish to fry and maize to prepare fante kenkey for sale.

By Abena's left hand, a row of fante kenkey is visible.  On her right side, there is a wooden tray with fried fish arranged for sale.

loans.use: To buy fish and maize.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old married man from Lebanon living with his wife and one child. He cooperates earning the family income with his wife who owns a home maid office.  After having13 years of experience in the clothing field, he decided in 2009 to open a clothing store. He purchases his products from a local clothing center. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase supplementary products to increase his sales and therefore his family’s financial level.

loans.use: To purchase supplementary products

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en:
Nestor R. is from the village of Samonte. He is 52 years old. Nestor is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Nestor owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Nestor has been engaged in his business for over 32 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nestor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nestor is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Nestor from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Chhiev's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of seventeen members. They are living in Prey Prasat village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Chhiev K., married woman, was born in 1972, and she is a village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. She is a congee (rice porridge) seller in the local village. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she would like to ask for a loan to purchase more congee supplies to enlarge her business activities. Her husband, Mr. Phang Sandap, is a construction worker. With their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family living. 

This couple is working to support their four children: three are attending a local school and the youngest is 3 years old.

loans.use: To purchase more congee  ( rice porridge) supplies to enlarge her business activities.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny and her husband are both farmers. They cultivate their land to plant and harvest rice crops. They are currently preparing their land for planting. Jenny, a member of CEVI, applied for a loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. This loan will truly help Jenny have a good harvest.

Jenny is 41 years old, married and has 2 children aged 10 and 8. She works hard to sustain her children's education. She dreams for them to have bright futures.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en:
Mrs. Pilar M., age 67, is a widow living in Dulapo, Oroquieta, Misamis Occidental. She has six children. After she learned about Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative, she got interested and joined the co-op in October 2002.

She has started a business running a sari-sari (variety) store. She is applying for a PHP 14,900 loan in order to buy additional goods. It is entirely thanks to the co-operative financing her endeavors that she is able to implement this project. She hopes her business will be more profitable and that she will see all her children become successful someday.

loans.use: to buy additional goods to offer for sale in her store

loans.name: Mwanabarawa

texts.en:
Mwanabarawa is a married woman with 5 school-going children. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past three years, she has operated a retail business selling household goods to her neighbors and passersby. She operates from Monday to Friday, selling consumable goods on a daily basis. 

Mwanabarawa faces a major challenge of theft because of insecurity in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. With the 30,000 KES loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase 10 bundles of maize flour, one sack of beans and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase 10 bundles of maize flour, one sack of beans and cooking oil

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok Y., age 58, has been cultivating rice crops on her own farmland for over ten years, in the province of Kompong Chhnang. Her husband earns a daily income by working on a fruit plantation. The couple usually generates a profit about $3.50 per day. They have given birth to seven children, all married now and most of them living separately.

Sok Y. says she is worried about the water system in her house. She always goes to her neighbor’s house when she needs to use water. It is not easy for her and her family to access water. Therefore, Sok Y. would like a loan to dig a well for her family's use. This loan will improve her living standard and make her family’s situation better. She dreams of opening a new grocery store.

loans.use: to dig a well for her family's use

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne C. is 33 years old and llives in Kakamega. She is married to Nelson. They have three children between the ages of eight and four.

She has a business of selling secondhand clothes. She has been in this business for the past nine years and has seen it grow through the years. She is applying for her second loan from KADET LTD and wants to use the money to buy more clothes to add to her stock.

Anne is very optimistic that her business will expand after she gets the loan. She hopes to open up a boutique in the future.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to add to her stock.

loans.name: María Alexandra

texts.es:
En el sitio la pila del cantón Montecristi se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal  Para el Futuro De la Mujer. Este lugar es muy conocido en la provincia y en el país por su rica cultura tradicional, donde se puede encontrar una gran variedad de  artesanía que son elaboradas por sus habitantes siguiendo las costumbres tradicionales.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora María, tiene 28 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijas de 8 y 2 años, la mayor  estudian en escuela. El marido es taxista.

Ella se dedica al comercio, tiene un local en el cual vende zapatos y sandalias de todo tipo, trabaja todos los días desde las 8h30 hasta las 17h00, nos cuenta que a veces se le hace muy difícil realizar este trabajo pero que lo hace por el bien de sus pequeñas hijas, trabaja con la ayuda de un cuñado que es quien se queda a cargo del trabajo cuando ella tiene que ir a atender  a sus hijas. Lleva 4 años con su negocio el cual  ha crecido mucho. Los productos los va a comprar a Guayaquil cada fin de mes.

Este crédito es para comprar más zapatos y sandalias  de todas las formas y modelos para surtir su negocio. Está  en el Banco Comunal hace 4 años y le gusta porque con el primer crédito ella empezó su negocio que le está brindando buenas satisfacciones.

Su sueño es tener un local más grande y propio.
texts.en:
The “Para el Futuro de la Mujer” (For Woman’s Future) communal bank meets every two weeks in La Pila, Montecristi Canton.  This place is very well known in the province and nationwide for its rich cultural tradition where one can find a wide variety of arts and crafts manufactured by its residents following traditional customs.

We met María, 28, here.  She’s in a common law relationship and has two daughters who are 8 and 2 years of age; the oldest is in school.  Her husband’s a Taxi Driver.

She is a merchant.  She has a locale where she sells shoes and sandals of all types.  She works daily from 8:30 until 5:00.  She tells us that sometimes doing the work is quite difficult but she does it for her young daughters’ sake.  She works with help from a brother-in-law who watches the store when she has to attend to her children.  She’s been in business for four years and it has grown much.  She stocks up on merchandise every end of the month in Guayaquil.

This loan is to buy more shoes and sandals in all shapes and styles to stock her business.  She’s been in the communal bank for 4 years and likes it because with the first loan she started her business that is providing good satisfaction.  Her dream is to have a larger locale of her own.

loans.use: to buy shoes and sandals.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby, age 34, runs a sar-sari (variety) retail shop business in the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City. She sells such items as canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in the local community. Ruby has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month from these activities. Ruby and her husband have two school-aged children.  

In 2010, Ruby joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruby has successfully repaid her most recent previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and was employed as working capital. Ruby is now requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and snack food items. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ruby from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack food items to offer for sale in her shop

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “LIDERANDO LAS PALMERAS”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito D. Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia D. Cusco y departamento D. Cusco.

La socia tiene 49 años D. edad y es casada y tiene 4 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio D. venta D. productos D. maíz y D. chuño, la socia lo trae D. lugares como Calca,pisaq y Urubamba y luego lo venD. en el mercado, ella trabaja desD. las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,por medio D. este negocio la socia saca adelante  a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio D. venta D. maíz. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar maíz y D. chuño al por mayor.
                                                            
 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos D. su cuota.
texts.en:
This borrower is a member of the "Liderando Las Palmeras" community bank which is located in Cusco district, in Cusco province and department.

The borrower is 49 years old, married, and has four children.  She divides her time between her daily activities and her business selling corn and 'chuño' (a freeze-dried potato product).  She buys her products in places such as Cala, Pisaq and Urubamba and then sells them in the local market.  She works from 8.00am to 6.00pm and, through this business, she gets her children ahead in life.  The borrower would like to expand her business selling corn.  She is requesting this loan to buy corn and 'chuño' wholesale.

The borrower is happy to be receiving the loan and pledges to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy corn and 'chuño' (freeze-dried potato product) wholesale

loans.name: Nueva Organización Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama nueva organización y se integra de cinco personas y que cada uno tiene su respectiva actividad.

    Las señora quine se le timo  la entrevista se llama María del  Carmen, vive en la Rivera san Vicente de Copainala estado de Chiapas México, ella es casada y a su responsabilidad  tiene a dos hijos  y son: Víctor Habrán de  ocho años de edad y el más pequeño es Emanuel de Jesús de cinco meses de edad.

     Ella se dedica  a la elaboración de panes y solicito  el préstamo para invertirlo en la compra de ingredientes  cono son: huevo, aceite, quesos, azúcar, entre otros, para luego venderlo en la misma  localidad, en la que comenta que le va bien ya que con ello obtiene  ingresos para su hogar.

     En esta actividad se inspiro ya que también quiere apoyar su esposo con lo ingreso de la casa y así juntos sacar adelante a su familia que es lo más importante para ella, en  esta actividad lleva  nueve años y cuatro meses y le está dando resultado.

    Su más grande deseo es que con esta actividad pueda trabajar y con  el préstamo apoyarse con la compra de más ingredientes para poder trabajar y así tener sus  propios  ahorros para  salir adelante.

      Las personas que se integran en el grupo son: Corazón de Jesús invierte el préstamo en la compra de mercancía para surtir su tienda de abarrotes, la señora Rafaelita se dedica a la elaboración de panes  para luego venderlo en la misma localidad, Vivían Ibis: compra y vende ropas, Sarita: se dedica a la compra y venta de pimienta para luego venderlo en la misma región.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Nueva Organización" has five members who each have their own businesses.

María del Carmen lives in Rivera san Vicente de Copainala, in the state of Chiapas, in México.  She is married and has two children:  Víctor Habrán, 8, and her youngest,Emanuel de Jesús, 5 months.  She makes bread for a living and is taking out a loan so she can buy ingredients like: eggs, oil, sugar, cheese, and other things.  Once she has made the bread, she sells it in her neighborhood.  She says that her business is doing well and she is making money for her family.  She started selling bread because she wanted to help her husband support the family and to help her family, the most important thing to her, get ahead.  She has been doing this for nine years and four months and is seeing a return on her investment.  

Her greatest desire is to be able to work doing what she is doing.  The loan will help her to buy more ingredients for her business and enable her to have her own savings so she can get ahead.  

The members of the communal bank are: Corazón de Jesús, who will invest her loan buying merchandise to stock her grocery store, la señora Rafaelita, who bakes and sells bread in her neighborhood, Vivían Ibis who buys and sells clothing, and Sarita who buys and sells chilies in the same region.

loans.use: para pagar la compra de ingredientes como son: huevo ,, harina, leche, queso, entre otrso., para la elaboración de panes.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SUMAC  AYLLU”; el banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito de Huanchac en la Provincia de Cusco y Departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Juana; la socia tiene 37 años de edad, la socia es conviviente, La socia tiene 3 hijos de 22, 19, 14; La socia tiene una chichería en su propia casa, la socia vende la famosa bebida inka elaborada a base de maíz y mediante un proceso de fermentación natural, la socia desea en esta ocasión el crédito para la compra de maíz y la elaboración de la famosa bebida de los inkas la chicha. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de maíz amarillo.

La socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the "SUMAC AYLLU" community bank, which is located in the Huanchac District in Cusco Province, Cusco Department.

The member is Señora Juana; the member is 37 years old, and lives with her partner.  The member has 3 children aged 22, 19 and 14.  The member has a chicheria in her own house, selling chicha ( a traditional drink).   The member sells the famous Incan drink which is made from a corn base through a process of natural fermentation.

The member is currently looking for the loan to invest in the purchase of yellow corn.

The member is grateful for the support which is being offered her, and similarly promises to comply in a disciplined manner with her repayments.

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of yellow corn.

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo is 51 years old and married to Susan. The couple is blessed with seven children. Danilo is thankful that his wife helps him to manage their rice farm. According to him, he is able to earn about 30,000 PHP every harvest season.

Danilo grows rice and has been doing this for 21 years. Due to insufficient capital, Danilo was encouraged to join ASKI and be part of their organization. He is asking for a loan of 25,000 PHP to further improve his rice farming business. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer and insecticides for his farm. He hopes that his loan request will be granted.

In the future, Danilo hopes to continue to improve his farm so that his profit will increase.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticides for his farm

loans.name: Juan Angel

texts.es:
Juan, tiene 30 años de edad, es soltero, vive únicamente con su madre, él es agricultor, cultiva maíz, de la producción abastece su hogar y comercializa una parte para obtener efectivo, tiene 10 años de estar realizando estas labores y fue su madre quien inicio la enseñanza del cultivo de maíz.
Él está solicitando un préstamo un préstamo para la compra de tres sacos de fertilizantes, estos son para aplicarlos al cultivo, con la intención de obtener una mejor producción para mejorar la alimentación y los ingresos del hogar. 
Su objetivo a largo plazo es mejorar su vivienda, ya que actualmente es de adobe y quiere reconstruirla con ladrillo de cemento, también la introducción de energía eléctrica, contribuyendo así a una mejor condición de vida con su madre.
texts.en:
Juan is 30 years old, single, and lives with his mother.  He is a farmer who raises corn which he uses to feed his household and also sells part of his harvest.  He’s been doing this for 10 years, an activity he learned from his mother.

He is asking for this loan in order to buy three sacks of fertilizer to spread on his crop, so that he can improve his production and have more from which to feed his household and provide an income.

His long term goal is to make improvements to his home.  It’s currently made of adobe and he wants to reconstruct it out of cement bricks and add electricity.  This will contribute to a better quality of life for his mother.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Assaad

texts.en: Assaad is a 33-year-old single man from Lebanon living with his parents. He learned the mechanic occupation when he was very young. And after gaining the needed experience, he opened his own car repair shop in 2009. He is very talented at his work, which consists of repairing vehicle’s bodies.  With his requested loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l, he will invest in purchasing new mechanical tools and supplies. He has a good business reputation and he is distinguished by his great customer service. His business needs many improvements and he notes that the loan will help him realize his intended objectives in a short term.

loans.use: to purchase new mechanical tools and supplies

loans.name: Juan Miguel

texts.es: Juan Miguel tiene 53 años de edad, es caficultor en pequeña escala, es casado y tiene seis hijos entre las edades de 17 y 5 años, y junto a su familia reside en la comunidad de El Guineo en el municipio de Patuca. Don Juan inició a dedicarse al cultivo de café gracias a que uno de sus cuñados le hizo un pequeño prestamo de dinero y tambien le regalara una area de tierra, tiene 20 años de dedicarse a este cultivo y el manejo lo aprendió de su padre ya que tambien se dedicaba a los mismo. Don Juan se siente muy agradecido con su cuñado porque gracias a él ahora tiene su propio negocio y tiene una entrada de dinero para sostener a su familia. Su desventaja es que la pequeña finca no esta tecnificada y eso le provoca costos adicionales y el peligro de las plagas es un verdadero dolor de cabeza. Pero su ventaja es que el café es un producto bastante comercializable y una vez que sale la produccion la vende rapido. El prestamo que esta solicitando en esta ocasion lo necesita para comprar melaza, fertilizantes, y pagar la mano de obra por la chapia de la tierra. Su meta es llegar a tener 10 mz de tierra cultivada y con el apoyo de este prestamo poco a poco lo irá logrando. Este es el primer ciclo de don Juan en FAMA y espera cumplir con el compromiso de sus pagos al dia.
texts.en:
Juan Miguel is 53 and a small scale coffee grower. He is married and has six children, from 5 to 17 years old. Together with his family he lives in El Guineo neighborhood in Patuca municipality. Juan Miguel began growing coffee thanks to one of his brothers-in- law who gave him a gift of a plot of land and provided him with a small loan. He has spent 20 years cultivating coffee, a task he learned how to do from his father who is himself a small coffee grower. 

Juan is very grateful to his brother-in-law because, thanks to him, he now has his own business and an income to support his family. He feels at a  disadvantage in that his small farm is not mechanized, which causes him to incur additional costs, and the danger of pest infestations is a real headache. However, he feels he has an advantage in that coffee is a very marketable product and once it is harvested he can sell it quickly. He is requesting this loan to buy weed killer, fertilizer and to pay a labor force to clear the land. His goal is to eventually have 10 mz. of land (one manzana = approximately 1.68 acres) under cultivation and with the support of this loan he will be able to achieve this, little by little . This is Juan’s first loan cycle at FAMA and he expects to fulfill his commitment to make all his payments on time.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and weed killer and to pay laborers.
